results.title: The Agony and the ecstasy
results.creator_credit: Carol Reed and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Based on Irving Stone’s mammoth bestseller, “The Agony and the Ecstasy” is the dynamic retelling of one of the fiercest and most productive collaborations in art history, that of artist and painter Michelangelo, and the man who commissioned him to paint the Sistine Chapel, Pope Julius II. As played by Charlton Heston (as the painter) and Rex Harrison (as the Pope), the men are both titanic egoists determined to leave eternity a unique vision of their love and faith for God. Though “the Agony and the Ecstasy” betrays an earlier era’s reluctance to deal with either Michelangelo’s ambivalent sexuality, or the Pope’s lustful material excesses, the emotionally violent duels between the men betray the deep extremes of hatred, jealousy and love which dominated their relationship. For a contemporary viewer it is the richly colourful cinematography and the epic reconstruction of Renaissance Rome which is the film’s long-lasting legacy. If the melodrama of the clashes between the tortured artist and the meglomaniac Pope now seem almost camp, the recreation of the feat of painting the vast Chapel still seems wondrous. Cast also includes Diane Cilento, Harry Andrews and Alberto Lupo.

results.title: The Bitter tea of General Yen
results.creator_credit: Frank Capra, Walter Wanger and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Idealistic American missionary Megan Davis (Barbara Stanwyck) braves the ravages of civil war in China to travel to Shanghai to wed Dr. Robert Strike (Gavin Gordon), the fiancee she hasn’t seen in three years. When Robert postpones the wedding to go and save a group of orphans stranded in the centre of a war zone, Megan demonstrates her devotion by accompanying him on his mission. After the last of the orphans are despatched to safety, Megan becomes separated from Robert, and is overcome by the panic-stricken crowds. She awakens to find herself on a military train, travelling to the Summer Palace of Chinese warlord General Yen (Nils Asther). Initially she is repulsed and frightened by both her alien surroundings and the Generals’ attempts to win her favour, and demands to be sent back to Shanghai. General Yen, however, finds himself fascinated by Megan’s feisty nature, and finds excuses not to send her back to her fiancee. Any chance of a relationship developing between the two is irrevocably destroyed when Yen’s mistress Mah-li (Toshia Mora) betrays both him and Megan, initiating a sequence of events which result in the downfall of the mighty General. Originally Columbia Pictures assigned this film to silent film director Herbert Brenon, with Frank Capra lobbying for and eventually winning the project after Brenon left the studio due to creative and financial differences. Controversial due to its principle theme of interracial romance, this moody, sensual production deviated from Capra’s usual filmic concerns with its touching yet dramatic depiction of doomed love, a factor which Capra allegedly hoped would earn him an Academy Award. The characterisation of the Chinese in this film seems quite racist by today’s standards, especially the casting of Swedish silent film star Nils Asther, in the title role, plus a fantasy sequence where a demonic General Yen menaces Megan in her bedroom. The controversy surrounding the potential romance between a Chinese man and an American woman saw the film being banned in some areas. “The Bitter Tea of General Yen” was adapted from Grace Zaring Stone’s 1930 romantic novel of the same name.

results.title: Quebec: duplessis et apres...
results.creator_credit: Paul Larose and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film establishes a parallel between the 1970 electoral campaign in Quebec and the 1936 campaign dominated by Maurice Duplessis. It shows the hope but also the uncertainty that existed in 1970. Had the Quiet Revolution really changed things in Quebec? Was it possible that a new leader would emerge on the political scene?

results.title: Rio Grande
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Merian C. Cooper and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: John Wayne is Lieutenant Colonel Kirby Yorke, a member of the US Cavalry defending the Rio Grande from attacking Apache Indians. His son Jeff, who he hasn’t seen for fifteen years, joins the unit and very soon after Yorke’s estranged wife (Maureen O’Hara) arrives to demand their son return home. Having lost his wife’s respect over his actions in the Civil War, Jeff’s arrival offers Yorke the opportunity to prove himself again to his wife. Their rekindled romance, however, is put at risk when a tribe of Apaches attack the lonely outpost community. Directed by veteran John Ford, this is a classically structured western film that features an outstanding group of character actors including Ben Johnson and Victor McGlaglen. If the depiction of the Native Americans may turn contemporary stomachs, the final action scenes are inarguably rousing and deftly executed.

results.title: Touch of evil = Badge of evil
results.creator_credit: Orson Welles, Albert Zugsmith and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Considered now to be Orson Welles’ finest movie after “Citizen Kane”, “Touch of Evil” confounded and confused American critics on its release who saw it as nothing more than a detective B-movie. However, European critics responded immediately to the film’s baroque excesses and acclaimed it as a masterpiece of film noir. Charlton Heston plays a Mexican narcotics cop who patrols a red-light town on the border between Mexico and the United States. He comes into conflict with the bloated, corrupt Quinlan (Orson Welles), and before long he is immersed in the dark, sinister world of borderland crime and punishment. The plot however is secondary to the rich mise-en-scene Welles employs to render an atmosphere of decadence and moral vacuity. The rich black and white cinematography conveys the heat and oppressiveness of a sweltering summer’s night; the music by Henry Mancini adds drama and tension to the narrative; the editing is fast and compulsive. Welles is also assisted by a range of terrific performances by Heston, Janet Leigh, Akim Tamiroff, Mercedes McCambridge and a wonderfully dissipated Marlene Dietrich. He himself is a stand-out as the evil but all too human Quinlan. From the opening introductory sequence, all shot in one long track (and justifiably one of the most famous sequences of film ever shot), “Touch of Evil” takes immediate visceral hold of the viewer and doesn’t let go until the bitter, explosive end. The studio may have thought it had convinced Welles to create a “happy ending”, but the memory of what went before can not quite be dispelled: “Touch of Evil” owes much more to existentialism and apocalyptic vision than it does to the mores and conventions of Hollywood.

results.title: Life on a string = Bian zou bian chang
results.creator_credit: Chen Kaige, Donald Ranvaud, China Film Co-Production Corporation, Beijing Film Studio, Pandora Films and Serene Productions
results.brief_description: A blind musician has sustained himself with the belief that his blindness can be cured, but only after he has broken 1000 strings on his sanxian (a traditional three-stringed guitar). Although he has broken 995 he is now an old man approaching death who continues to roam the countryside with his restless young disciple promoting peace and harmony. This is not a conventional narrative, but a fable with an epic quality which explores the chasm between faith and magic, authority and disobedience, sacrifice and consummation. Kaige sees it as a plea for the rejuvenation of Chinese culture, civilization and identity, a plea which the Chinese authorities saw to be in some way subversive since they banned the film’s circulation in China. Cast includes Liu Zhongyuan, Huang Lei, Xu Qing. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: A Night to remember [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Sidney Hayers, Roy Baker, William MacQuitty and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description: The dramatic story of the first sailing and sinking of the ocean liner, “Titanic” in 1912. “RMS Titanic”, the liner they said was unsinkable, struck an iceberg and sank with the loss of 1500 lives. The film faithfully depicts the heroism and horror of the night the unthinkable happened. Starring Kenneth More, Laurence Naismith and David MacCallum as the radio operator. From the book by Walter Lord.

results.title: Looking for Alibrandi [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Robyn Kershaw, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Premium Movie Partnership and AFFC
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by first time writer Melina Marchetta, “Looking for Alibrandi” is an affectionate look at three generations of strong willed Italian women, and the youngest member, Josie’s (Pia Miranda) attempt to break the family “curse”. 17 year old Josie lives with her single mother Christina (Greta Scacchi), is completing her HSC at an exclusive Sydney school on a scholarship, begrudgingly visiting her Nonna, defending the labels of “wog” and “bastard”, and longing after the lifestyle afforded to rich kids with both parents. When her father, Michael (Anthony La Paglia) enters their lives again, Josie confronts her mother and her Nonna about the rift between Christina and her father, and the animosity between mother and daughter to reveal secrets long since hidden. Josie must also make decisions about her future career and what her heart desires as she is torn between school captain John Barton (Matthew Newton) and public school boy Jacob (Kick Gurry). Between work, school, family and personal relationships, Josie discovers that life is filled with uncertainty and she is not the only one debilitated by the labels society ascribes. This was the first feature film effort for both director Woods and actor Miranda. Remarkably, the film was nominated and won several AFI awards, including best film, best supporting actress (Scacchi) and best performance by an actress in a leading role (Miranda).

results.title: New Dragon Gate Inn = Dragon Inn
results.creator_credit: Raymond Lee Wai-Man, Tsui Hark, Seasonal Film Corporation and Film Workshop
results.brief_description: In this rousing martial arts epic set in China during the Ming dynasty (1368-1644), silver-haired eunuchs who control much of the country’s wealth, and murder those who oppose them, kidnap two children. The children are rescued by an Imperial swordsman and his female companion. With the eunuchs’ forces in hot pursuit, the escaping party takes shelter at a mysterious isolated tavern called the Dragon Inn run by a murderous hostess. An atmospherically tense action-drama with spectacular fight sequences and cinematography. Remake of 1966 film “Dragon Inn” (“Longmen Kezhan”) by King Hu. In Cantonese and Mandarin with English subtitles. Cast includes Maggie Cheung, Brigitte Lin, Tony Leung and Donnie Yen.

results.title: The Magic sword: quest for Camelot
results.creator_credit: Frederick DuChan, Dalisa Cohen and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in the time of King Arthur, a renegade knight sets out to seize power by stealing the sword Excalibur. Brave Hayley, who longs to become a knight, sets out together with a young blind hermit, a dragon and a falcon, to foil his plot, recover the magic sword, and save the kingdom. Featuring the voices of Cary Elwes, Gary Oldman, Eric Idle, Pierce Brosnan and Sir John Gielgud.
